xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: 0.127 APPLICATIONS OF STABLE ISOTOPES AND MASS SPECTROMETRY TO THE STUDY OF GLYCOGEN SYNTHESIS FROM GLUCOSE IN LIVER CELLS. J.P. Riou, S. Normand, H. Vidal, R. Guilluy, M. Beylot, INSERM U.197, Faculte de Medecine A. Carrel, 69372 Lyon. We have examined the pathway of glycogen synthesis from glucose (G) in isolated rat liver cells from fasted rats by using 1-13 C glucose as tracer and the analysis of the site of labelling of the glucose molecule in the glycogen by gaz chromatography-mass spectrometry. The hypothesis is that the indirect route described in vivo for glycogen synthesis (glucose.+ lactate -+ glycogene) exists in the liver owing to the presence in the liver of glycolytic and neoglucogenic liver cells. If this pathway exists the carbon 1 of G must be randomized to the position 1-6 or 2-5 in glycogen. If it doesn't only 1-C should be labelled. The measurement in glycogen of the isotopic ratio M+1/M+M+l and M+2/M+M+2 should differentiate these two pathways. When the isolated liver cells are incubated for 2 h in the presence of 8 mM glutamine, 8 mM glycerol and 10 mM G (isotopic enrichment (IE) 50 %) net glycogen synthesis occured mainly during the second hour of incubation (38 yMol glycosyl units.g' ) no net utilisation of glucose occured, utilisation of glycerol accounts for both glycogen synthesis and glucose production. The relative IE of glucose in glycogen measured at M+l increases during the first hour and remains stable. On the opposit the relative IE measured at M+2 increases significantly from 35 % to 65 % only during the active phase of glycogen synthesis. In conclusion, these results suggest that in isolated liver cells, although isotopic exchange of carbon occurs, glycogen synthesis from glucose may follow the indirect pathway described in vivo. This finding may have important implication in the study of glucose metabolism during parenteral nutrition. 0.128 EVALUATION OF A CHEMILUMINESCENT iJITRDGEN ANALYSIS TECHNIQUE FOR USE IN NUTRITIONAL ASSESSMENT STUDIES. R Drummond, L Mazzagatti, P Guthrie, M Malias, S Oudrick (Dept of Nutritional Support Services, St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital, Houston, Texas, USA) One of the hallmarks of nutritional assessment of the protein-calorie status of patients is dependent upon accurate nitrogen balance studies. These determinations require nitrogen analysis of feces, urine and other excretory body fluids (e.g., perspiration). Traditionally, analysis of urinary nitrogen has been accomplished using the Kjeldahl technique which is extremely laborious, and potentially dangerous to laboratory personnel. We are currently completing an evaluation of a fully automated chemiluminescent nitrogen analyzer (Antek Instruments) in which analysis time is minimal (30 sec), and sensitivity is in the picogram range. Attenuation of the instrument ranges from 1 to 5000. At an attenuation of 20, a 5 microliter Injection of ammonia standards varying from 2 to 40 Ugm nitrogen results in a 7 point curve (r=0.999). Standard curve stability studies over a 45 day period (n=11) produced a slope of 13.4.46 with between run precision for all standards averaging 45% coefficient of variation (CV%). Urine spike/recovery studies showed parallelism throughout the linear range. Sample stability studies revealed that acidified urines at 24, 4 and -20 degrees C were stable for up to 10 days with variation in detector responses ,V'06. Within run precision of urine specimens (n=20) at 4.48 and 20.31 ugN exhibited CV% of 0.74% and 0.3% respectively. Between-run precision (n=20) studies of urine samples of 4.69 and 21.63 UgN revealed CV4b of 2.3% and 1.1% respectively. Urinary nitrogen values (n=47) obtained by Kjeldahl and chemiluminescent measurements revealed a direct correlation (n=0.97) with a slope of 0.99 and Y intercept of 1.36. Based on preliminary evaluations, the simplicity, safety and precision of nitrogen analysis by chemiluminescence will render Kjeldahl nitrogen analysis obsolete. 94

head.ce:title: Evaluation of a chemiluminescent nitrogen analysis technique for use in nutritional assessment studies
head.ce:subtitle: R Drummond, L Mazzagatti, P Guthrie, M Malias, S Dudrick (Dept of Nutritional Support Services, St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital, Houston, Texas, USA)
